segments.text: our woods hole people had made any real comparisons between them so first i chose lamont one to use here at the same time that the regular woods holding was being used and then chose another one later and we kept on experimenting until we got the one we think was the best that was the best another problem was out of the sound source and so we built
Heretofore at Woods Hole we'd been using sparkers, so we built a big sparker.
It was bigger than the one that the others had here, that's right.
And then finally we went on to air guns, and now continue to use those.
Another aspect was the receiving of the detection of the echoes, and so we made a new kind of a detection array.
Not really very complicated, but one with about 200 detectors in it.
And the people at Woods Hole began using that about the same time, so it's hard to know who was first on it.
Then we wanted to improve the system, so eventually we started digitizing the single channel.
That was really near the end of the geological survey participation.
And then after it was digitized, then we could stack and deconvolve and do other things with it.
And then finally that led to using two multi-channel arrays.
The ship is out now with a 12-channel multi, 12-channel assessment reflection equipment.
What sort of conclusions are you reaching with sounding at this time?

Well, what we are mainly interested in and have been here at the institution is to learn much about the origin of the continental slope and the shelf and rise, in effect, to know why continents exist and what the difference is between the continents and the ocean basins.
In the process of doing that, of course, then we learn a lot about the structure of the continental margin.
particularly the shelf and the slope.
And very often this structure shows the potential, the areas of potential oil and gas provinces.
It doesn't locate places to drill.
It doesn't locate oil fields, but it locates wide regions that have potential.
And on the east coast here, one of the first things that we did was to show that

was to compare the seismic reflection work that we did with previous work that Lamont had done with seismic refraction and to verify and extend the presence of large potential oil and gas distributions beneath the shelf, actually beneath George's Bank in what is now known as the Baltimore Canyon region and farther south near Jacksonville.
Those areas were mapped about 1963, 63 or 64, with the statement as necessary to drill holes to find out whether there actually is any oil and gas present.
The areas still haven't been leased offshore.
And so it's clear that the problem facing the people of the United States is a lack of interest in the part of the government on finding energy supplies rather than to
find sources of revenue for the Treasury.

So, of course, this sort of thinking soon led to an emphasis on political oceanography, and there's a tremendous amount of that, for example, by the United Nations, with manganese nodules and other things.
So it's a different kind of a field.
I've been interested in that, because it's just one more obstacle for marine geologists.
And you remained then in this kind of work here at Woods Hole.
Yes.
I've been here now 15 years, and most of that time has been spent on geophysics.
And it's now time for another change, or it was a few years ago.
So I've changed now to synthesis of large aspects of oceanography.
first by working with one of my associates, a former student, Elazar Yachupi, on a memoir for the Western North Atlantic Ocean.
It was published by the American Association of Petroleum Geologists.
This was in 1972, which was a pretty good time for it to come out.
And it was kind of a parallel to the book of Southern California.
And now we are working together on another one, a synthesis for the entire Atlantic Ocean.
60 degrees south to 60 degrees north.
That's the stratigraphy of the Atlantic, the structure of it, the sediments, the rocks, the relationship to the biology and to the physical oceanography, currents and waves and so forth.
So this will keep us out of mischief for another couple years.
Yeah, I should think so.
I have now several questions concerning what amounts to the development of oceanography in terms of money.
By the way, how did you miss service in the O&R office?
I was asked at the very beginning in 1950, I think, but I was rather more interested in teaching.
And in the research, it was completely evident that one can't do research
administration at the same time.
In fact, many people make the mistake of thinking they can teach, do research, and administer all at the same time, and no one is successful at doing all three of them.
You can do one successfully and sometimes one and a half successfully.
So going to ONR would have been the wrong direction.
I chose the same way as far as being dean here, too.
You can't administer as a dean and do any effective research either.
button, so therefore your career has always pointed towards research and teaching.
Yeah, and since I left the University of Illinois, University of Southern California, not teaching.
I taught there 15 or 16 years and enjoyed it very much.
In fact, the students wrote a little book in commemoration when I left there, dedicated to me.
But the
After 15 years of teaching, you don't really expect to find many new experiences in teaching.
So I would rather go to something new and different rather than repeat the old.
I have had one or two students here.
One is the number one.
Now the number one is really marine geologist.
But when you came to Woods Hole, was there even a teaching program here?
No, that didn't begin until five years later.
OK.
six years later in 1968.
I was the first dean, acting dean.
An acting dean is, of course, by definition, a mouse learning to be a rat.
In the beginnings, if I may use that word, like 45, 46, 47 and so, it was almost as if block grants were given to institutions.
by ONR and what have you.
And then you drew your monies that way.
I didn't think the ONR began until 1950.
Well, it didn't.
I'm talking about the first grants to come out of the Naval office and then in the early years of the ONR.
Yeah.
At that time, I didn't ask for any because just going into teaching, there was enough to do there for a while.
OK. That was what I wanted to know.
When did you start?
And then in addition,

Captain Alan Hancock, who was a great beneficiary of the University of Southern California, built a new ship called the Valero IV, and it was available in 1947 for cruises in all phases of oceanography.
So I used that ship quite a lot in those days.
So you had enough ship time then without looking for research rates?
Yeah.
When did you begin to have your research funded by the government?
We started working on the sort of expensive parts of the sediment work, where we had to buy new equipment and pay salaries of assistants and so forth.
So I guess the first of those was probably about 1948, I suppose, after we'd gotten some cores from using Laurel 4.
That was with Rittenberg and Wilson-Ower.
With whom did you make contact first for money?
Probably Gordon Little, who was the head of the ONR at that time.
I think that's who it was.
He's now, I don't know where he is now.
Noah.
Oh, yes, that's right.
He went to Noah by way of lucky.
Right.
Did you...
Did you find it necessary then to issue a formal proposal?
Probably.
I've forgotten now, but yeah, I would have.
I made proposals whenever there were agencies to make them to, and never had any great problem with the money.
In fact, Shell Oil Company provided, I think, about $40,000 for general work on
on porphyrin pigments in the sediments, which we're interested in, and that money hasn't been so much of a problem.
For the geological survey work, I think the budget there, not counting salaries of their own people, came to something like an average of half a million a year, probably.
And then at the end of that,
started work on an African program, the entire west coast of Africa, and $2.5 million was provided.
That includes the price, the cost of the ship time, by ideally an half a decade of ocean exploration.
It was a five-year program.
Oh, yes, and before that, then, I'd done work along the Asian coast, from Korea down to Java, and this was partly funded by
by the Navy through mainly bureau ships, I think, and by National Science Foundation.
And a lot of it is just done without any funding.
But I'm to take it, though, that largely that money was not any problem in terms of... No, it didn't seem to be.
It hasn't seemed to be.
Is that still true?
Well, it is for me because a couple years ago,
I was given a big, low chair here, which provides salary and allows me to work on what I want to work on.
So if at the time I'm holding that, if I went out to seek funds to do specified work, it'd be a poor use of the funds for the chair.
With the funds for the chair, I can work on the synthesis here without spending time raising funds.
Good, good.
It's your impression that funds available for oceanography
or declining?
Well, I think the funds are increasing.
But the funds are declining if you put it in terms of constant dollars.
For example, here, that's more political oceanography.
But here at the Oceanographic Institution, the funds in 1971 were about $12 million for operations.
And in 76, they were $23 million.
But if you put them in terms of $1967, it's constant funding.
That means then that effectively the $11 additional revenue between 19, the annual revenue between 1971 and 77 really is just keeping up with the devaluation of the dollar.
Now, it's clear that
that the funds, even the inflated funds for small organizations, small oceanographic organizations, are falling and have fallen.

And that's not unreasonable because there are only three or four places that are large enough and have people who are experienced enough in all fields of oceanography so they can tackle large problems.
Of course, there's an argument about whether people, research workers, should work on smaller and smaller problems
know more and more about less and less, or the other way, less and less about more and more.

But in any case, the large institutions, that is, Woods Hole, Lamont, Scripps, chiefly those are ones where large problems can be tackled and are being tackled, large multi-institution, multinational programs.
are being undertaken just mostly by those.
The other places sometimes supply individuals to work, but they can't, mostly they can't be deeply involved in it, because they don't have the people.
Now, the funding itself is sort of everything.
For a program like Africa, I considered the funding to be one quarter of the job.
The politics, another quarter, you have to get permission from.
And there's a lot of problems, even in spite of the
in spite of and not helped by the State Department, so to speak.
Then there's the problem of technology.
You have to invent new equipment to improve on the previous ones.
And then finally, there's the science that you do it all for.
So in effect, a large program calls for all four of these.
And there are a lot of large programs that are developed.
In fact, one can tie this to different phases of oceanography.
For biology.
the greatest paradigm or generalization was that of Darwin's, who showed the effects of environment on the production of species and the distribution of species.
And since that time, lots of the biologists have been sort of proving that and not so much developing new approaches.
It's the broad generalization
of more than 100 years ago that's kind of rested new approaches in the field of biology.

In chemistry, on the other hand, the challenge of exploration of about 100 years ago, I had a man named Dittmar who did the chemistry of the waters and found that the ions bear a fairly constant ratio of each other throughout the oceans.
That was his main generalization.
It was a new generalization, and it's a useful one.
Now the main interest is to find in what ways the elements depart from the close ratio.
In other words, what are the anomalies, and what are those anomalies due to?
Some are due to evaporation, some to influx of seawater, some to, many of them, to biological influences.
Others are due to seafloor circulation associated with the plate tectonics.
For physical oceanography, the main generalization was by a man named Bjorknes in the
in Norway, and he showed that you could measure the dynamic height of the ocean surface and from that compute currents in the same way you'd do currents with wind, with meteorological observations.
That was a broad generalization.
And that was followed for a long time.
Now the main approach is the knowledge that those currents
make up only a small amount of the movement in the ocean, perhaps only 1%.
The rest is turbulence.
And in order to learn about broad turbulence, it's necessary to make synoptic observations at many points at the same time.
So the physical oceanographers mainly are dealing with buoys.
Many buoys in the ocean record for several months.
The geologists were very slow, in a way.
They were the last to form a broad generalization.
And that was formed only a decade ago.
It's the plate tectonics hypothesis.
or theory, and now that's served as a framework into which many kinds of marine geology can now be fitted.
How did we get into this?
We got into this because after these generalizations, we have to look for anomalies and details that weren't appreciated and weren't needed and weren't understood beforehand.
And these are more expensive ways of working.
Now, in order to do this, we have several programs going on here.
One was the famous expedition using the submarines in the middle Atlantic Ocean.

We wanted to make a continuation of that in a different environment, so we made studies in the Cayman Trough last year, and then this year, similar sort of thing in the Galapagos rise from the area sea floor spreading in Galapagos.
Each of these three areas happens to be
areas of active seafloor spreading, but each is vastly different.
Each has unexpected fallout.
Galapagos people came back all enthusiastic because in addition to the very useful geological observations, they found many deep-sea clams a foot or so long living at a depth of 2,800 meters.
There's no obvious source of food for them except oxidation of the hydrogen sulfide from the escaping bottom water.
that was escaping bottom water.
It's seawater that had been drawn into the area of seafloor spreading and expelled after it heated and picked up some elements and lost its oxygen, picked up hydrogen sulfide.
Anyway, all these multidisciplinary, multi-equipment types of studies are very expensive.
And the small wind stations cannot
cannot man them or staff them usually.
Go ahead.
In your work towards a broad synthesis that you're aiming for, do you see a work towards broad synthesis in all fields of oceanography?
Yeah, certainly that's true.
I mentioned the
biology, the chemistry, the physics, and the geology.
The chemistry one is well illustrated by the geosex work, which very sophisticated equipment was used for investigating the anomalies of ratios and other things.
The biology is farther behind.

The biology work has taken some interesting new approaches, however, though, measuring the metabolic activity of benthic organisms through using submarines to place units on the bottom to trap water associated with organisms and find out how much, how fast the oxygen is used to recover the equipment for the submarine and measure the changes.
One of the interesting things is to find that the metabolic activity is very low, therefore the animals may live for several hundred years, maybe some of them a thousand years.
This first came to light in a way by finding that when we lost our submarine for ten and a half months, the sandwiches that were in the submarine were pretty well preserved.
When they finally recovered, though, they'd been destroyed by bacteria at the surface.
Butter and bacteria are not used to sandwiches.
But it's cold and high pressure, and both the cold and the high pressure reduces the metabolic activity.
If you were offering advice to a young oceanographer on what direction he should direct his career, what would you tell him?
Well, this happens very often.

I tell them to get a first-class degree, bachelor's degree, in one of the major fields of oceanography before they start specializing in the ocean so that they'll know enough about one field to be able to handle it well.
The places that have turned out bachelor's degree oceanographers give a smattering of things that people don't generally know enough to do any effective work.
I don't know of any graduates from that who've gotten their doctorates, but there may be some.
I recommend that you take, if you were to be a geologist, that you take all two courses in biology, chemistry, and physics.
In fact, you ought to have a thorough background so as to be able to build that.
Now, this is different from what the students nowadays want to do.
Most students want to become specialists.
I always used to tell my students that they should be generalists, and they'll know when to hire a specialist.
They'll also know when the specialist has come to the point of diminishing returns and be able to fire him.
And some of the students have taken that advice.
They're now presidents of companies and so forth.
And after he's received, then,
firm scientific education, and is choosing a career in oceanography.
What branch of oceanography should he move into?
Of course, that depends entirely on the man, what the man's interests are.
I have recommended to some people in each of the different fields.
It really depends, and the man's interests are usually developed accidentally through
through having a family friend who may be a geologist or a family friend who may be a biologist.
And it's just an accident what people become interested in.
Very few people, I suppose very few people, go into a field that a vocational expert is selected for.
I don't know of any.
But it's usually an accident.
Mine was an accident.
of getting a grafting job with Shepard Purex.
If another job available to Illinois, as far as I know, that was the only one, then I might be in some other field.
Many fields are interesting.
Pacto was once going to be an archaeologist, and I talked with a professional archaeologist, and he gave about the same advice that Ravel had given.

a field where in order to be successful you have to have a private income of your own which i didn't happen to have but now i've been finding it interesting to work in the field of archaeology of the ocean floor and i still come back to it occasionally archaeology of the ocean floor yeah sure you don't mean nautical archaeology no not necessarily for example
At the height of the past, of the last, latest glacier, about 14,000 years ago, the whole shelf was exposed because sea level was low.
Man lived out on the shelf.
There were lots of elephants out there.
We'd find their teeth and so forth.
Lots of oysters, lots of fish, lots of birds, lots of small games.
There's no reason why man shouldn't have been there.
And on the east coast of North America, lots of dated, carbon-dated manned sites are known on land as far back as
12,000 years.
There's a great influx of people about 12,000 years ago.
In fact, it's thought that as these people progressed across northern North America, they practiced overkill and had to move out as they eliminated the elephants and the bison and the larger animals.
And so, people lived on the shelf.
We really haven't very good evidence for their being there, but we have good evidence of being on the shore, and they certainly would have gone on the shelf, regardless of whether the shelf was a
whether they knew they were on the ocean floor or not.
For example, if you ask the people in New York City if they're living on the ocean floor, of course they'd say no.
But if all the glaciers were to melt, the sea level would rise about 60 meters, about 200 feet.
It would cover all except the
about 30-story buildings.
So they're living on the ocean floor, so no reason why people shouldn't have lived on the ocean floor before.
I had no idea there was... You're not systematically cataloging sites out there, though, are you?
Yeah, well, not so much sites as things relate to it.
We found about 50 elephant teeth on the seafloor and probably at least a dozen freshwater peats on the seafloor that we accommodated.
The peats show that there were forests and meadows.
The elephants, some elephants occupied the meadows and some of the forests.
A lot of other animals, too.
Deer, elk, sloths.
The small animals, like rabbits and so forth, have bones that are too fragile to be preserved.
At least we haven't found any yet.
There are probably some who went to the right places.
And there had to be early man out there, too.
But man's burials, lots of the early man perhaps didn't make burials.
So bones just decompose at the surface.
And if they buried them, then of course, that's harder to find them then.
But it's an important thing.
Now, of course, nowadays we have people in the government bureaus who insist that archaeological work be done before offshore development is done.
But there's a difference between the requirements and the efficiency of the search.
the response to that requirement.
I don't think they're fine with her.
Most are found by amateurs, I think.
Yeah.
Yeah.
But I didn't know that they had impact studies for offshore.
Yeah, they do.
They all shall not build offshore wells without first having made an archaeological survey.
And if you find evidence of it, then, of course, you're not supposed to build a well there.
But same way for roads on the land.
